question.text: During the analysis of the DNA of an organism having 5386 nucleotides, it was discovered that the percentages of the bases were <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>29</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>32</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></math> . Considering the Chargaff's rule it can be concluded that:

options.text: It is a double-stranded linear DNA.
It is a double-stranded circular DNA.

Both  <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mo> </mo><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></mfenced></math>

solution.text: According to Chargaff's rule in any double stranded DNA <math><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow></mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> . That is in any double stranded DNA Amount of Adenine and Thymine should be same, as well as amount of Guanine and Cytosine should be same. Although amount <math><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is mostly not equal to 1, it is called Dissymmetry ratio.
